author: Andrew Thomson
title: Life turnaround: Offender's new path with NDIS support | The Standard | Warrnambool, VIC
text:
An offender with an acquired brain injury previously jailed a number of times has been placed on good behaviour bonds after turning around his life through the support of the NDIS.
Travis Hutchinson, 27, appeared in the Warrnambool Magistrates Court on Wednesday, April 22, charged with unlicensed riding of an unregistered monkey bike and three counts of theft.
He had also been charged with two breaches of corrections orders.
The court heard at 2pm on September 30 last year Hutchinson was caught riding an unregistered monkey bike near Kennedy Street.
Hutchinson told police he was "too lazy to walk", that he was trying to get a licence and riding the motorbike was "just stupid".
Police also reported that Hutchinson stole items including grips and oil from a motorbike shop on October 4, took two roofing kit bags from a Garden Street address mid the same month and then took a bottle of methylated spirits from Portland Disposals on October 21.
When police raided his home they found one of the kit bags.
Hutchinson also admitted prior court appearances, including him being jailed in June last year for more serious offending.
His lawyer said Hutchinson finished his jail term and returned to Portland but was homeless and that's when he committed the most recent offending.
NDIS support kicks in - major changes
His lawyer said that since then Hutchinson had got NDIS support, had supported accommodation in Terang and had now started working on a dairy farm.
She said Hutchinson had committed stupid offending, he struggled to comply with his CCOs but his offending had now de-escalated, he was settled in Terang and had supports in place, which all appeared to be working as there was no new offending.
Magistrate Kimberley Swadesir told Hutchinson that it fell to her to resentence him in relation to the corrections orders and for new offending - including stealing items from three people.
She said those property owners had suffered because Hutchinson wanted items that he could not afford.
Hutchinson was ordered to pay about $290 restitution to those people.
Ms Swadesir said she had considered Hutchinson's past offending, the most recent charges and the significant changes in his life including the NDIS support, his new job on a dairy farm and his accommodation.
Hutchinson was placed on three individual three-month good behaviour bonds with conditions he follow the directions of his NDIS support workers, not use illicit drugs and not offend again.

author: sidra
title: Drama Serial Bajjo Criticized for Bold Dressing
text:
Bajjo is Geo TV’s popular soap serial which airs daily at 7:00 pm. The drama has been directed by Mazhar Moin. It has been written by Javeria Saud. The cast features Javeria Saud, Suqaynah Khan, Arez Ahmed, Hashaam Khan, Sana Askari, Ayesha Gul. Shamyl Khan and Zohreh Aamir. The story of the drama revolves around a disobedient and stubborn eldest daughter Bajjo who couldn’t marry due to multiple societal pressures.
Recently, Drama serial Bajjo’s episode 35 is making headlines on social media due to its bold dressing. In the drama episode, actress Zohreh Aamir wore a revealing Saree in her wedding reception scene. Here are a few pictures from the drama episode:
Social media users are of the view that these dramas makers are gradually normalizing obscenity through dramas and Pakistani dramas viewers are becoming accustomed to such content and it will not bother them in few years. Many said that actresses should refuse to wear bold dresses in the dramas. Fans are saying that Pakistani dramas are now taking their inspiration from Star Plus content because they don’t have strong stories to offer. A social media user wrote, “no girl wears such revealing clothes in her reception” Read the comments here:

author: TASS
title: Russian diplomat informs UN head’s emissary about Kiev’s crimes against children
text: MOSCOW, September 26. /TASS/. Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergey Vershinin met with Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict Virginia Gamba to inform her about crimes against children committed by members of the Ukrainian armed forces, the Russian foreign ministry said in a statement. "The Russian side reaffirmed its commitment to full compliance with norms of the international humanitarian law in the course of the special operation, including with the goal of preventing casualties among children. Also, Virginia Gamba’s attention was drawn to atrocities committed by the armed forces of Ukraine, which resulted in numerous casualties among minors," the Russian foreign ministry said in a statement. The sides held a detailed exchange of opinions on bilateral cooperation in the context of preventing serious harm to children during armed conflicts in various parts of the globe. "Special attention was paid to the Ukrainian crisis, the situation in the Gaza Strip and Sudan," the Russian foreign ministry said.
